[[3rd Brigade (Australia)|3rd Brigade]]
[[2nd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]] |unit = |battles = Operation Lagoon
[[International Force for East Timor]] |awards = [[Officer of the Order of Australia]] |laterwork = }} [[Lieutenant General (Australia)|Lieutenant General]] '''David Lindsay Morrison''' [[Order of Australia|AO]] (born 1956) is a senior officer within the [[Australian Army]], currently serving in the position of [[Chief of Army (Australia)|Chief of Army]]. ==Early life and career== David Morrison joined the Australian Army in 1979, after completing a [[Bachelor of Arts]] at the [[Australian National University]]. He graduated from the Officer Cadet School, Portsea into the [[Royal Australian Infantry Corps]].[http://www.defence.gov.au/leaders/army/davidMorrison/index.htm ADF Biography] Between 1987 and 1988, Morrison served as the Australian Instructor at the [[Royal Military Academy, Sandhurst]], in the [[United Kingdom]]. In 1992, Morrison attended [[Army Command and Staff College, Queenscliff]], and was then appointed as the Brigade Major of the [[3rd Brigade (Australia)|3rd Brigade]], based in [[Townsville]], [[Queensland]]. During that time he took part in Operation Lagoon, acting as chief of staff for a multinational force that provided security to the peace conference held in [[Bougainville Island|Bougainville]] during 1994. The following year he was promoted to [[lieutenant colonel]]. In 1997 he was appointed as the Commanding Officer of the [[2nd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]], holding that position until the end of 1998, when he was posted as Chief Instructor Command, Staff Operations Wing at the Army All Corps Promotion Training Centre in Canungra. He was awarded [[Member of the Order of Australia]] in 1999 for his services as Brigade Major, Director of Preparedness and Mobilisation and CO of 2RAR.[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=878857&search_type=quick&showInd=true It's an Honour entry - Member of the Order of Australia] Upon promotion to [[colonel]] in October 1999, Morrison was appointed as Colonel Operations, Headquarters [[International Force for East Timor]] (INTERFET). On his return to Australia, he was posted to the [[Deployable Joint Force Headquarters]] as Chief of Staff. He left that position at the end of 2001 to attend the Centre for Defence and Strategic Studies, Canberra, where he graduated in 2002 with a [[Master of Arts (postgraduate)|Master of Arts]] in Strategic Studies. Morrison was promoted to [[brigadier]] in November 2002, and commanded the [[3rd Brigade (Australia)|3rd Brigade]] from December 2002 until December 2004. He was then appointed as Director-General Preparedness and Plans - Army (DGPP-A) and held that position until his promotion to [[Major General (Australia)|major general]] in December 2005. He was appointed Commander of the [[Australian Defence College]] in January 2006, and Head Military Strategic Commitments in April 2007. Morrison took up the appointment of Deputy Chief of Army in February 2008, replacing Major General [[John Patrick Cantwell]]. He served in this position until December, when he was appointed Land Commander Australia (LCAUST). Following a re-structure in July 2009, the post of Land Commander Australia was re-designated as Commander Forces Command. Morrison was appointed an [[Officer of the Order of Australia]] in the [[Australia Day]] Honours List of 2010.[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1141714&search_type=advanced&showInd=true It's an Honour entry - Officer of the Order of Australia] Morrison was promoted to [[Lieutenant General (Australia)|lieutenant general]] on 23 June 2011, and assumed the post of [[Chief of Army (Australia)|Chief of Army]] in a ceremony the following day.{{cite web|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/media/DepartmentalTpl.cfm?CurrentId=12029|title=Army Celebrates Leadership|accessdate=24 June 2011|work=Defence Media Release|publisher=Australian Department of Defence}} ==Honours and Awards==
